awd_titl_txt: Evaluating the Impact of Future Volcanic Eruptions on Stratospheric Ozone:  Influence of Multicomponent Injection, Climate Change, Latitude, and Seasonality
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on investigating the potential impacts of future volcanic eruptions on stratospheric ozone.  Stratospheric ozone shields the Earth from harmful ultra-violet radiation and hence it is important to understand how volcanic eruptions might impact stratospheric chemistry leading to changes in the protective ozone layer.

The primary objectives of this proposal are threefold: (1) characterize column ozone sensitivity to contemporary and future explosive volcanic eruptions as a function of volcanic latitude and season; (2) determine ozone column sensitivity to the direct stratospheric co-injection of inorganic chlorine, bromine, and iodine along with sulfur dioxide from volcanic eruption; and (3) quantify future bromine and iodine alpha factors (the relative ozone-destroying activity of bromine and iodine relative to chlorine) in a variety of greenhouse gas emission scenarios.

The effort will employ the SOlar Climate Ozone Links model with aerosol microphysics (SOCOL-AER) for the majority of the scenarios.  The chemical transport model AER-2D will also be used to quantify the sensitivity of stratospheric ozone for elements of the project where dynamics play a less significant role.  A postdoctoral fellow will perform many of the experiments and the work will provide opportunities for the development of research skills by undergraduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Large, explosive volcanic eruptions, such as the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in 1991 and Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai in January 2022, have potential to perturb the stratospheric ozone layer, which is critical for protecting life on this planet from harmful ultraviolet radiation. This NSF-funded project was undertaken to improve our understanding of realistic, modern volcanic eruption scenarios and better constrain the uncertainties regarding the response of stratospheric ozone following future explosive eruptions. In a separate modeling effort, the project sought to quantify the relative ozone-destroying activity of bromine and iodine relative to chlorine in future climate change scenarios.

All project objectives were successfully accomplished. The volcano modeling project, which spanned several years of work, resulted in the most comprehensive study ever undertaken to explore the impact on stratospheric ozone of an explosive volcanic eruption as a function of latitude, season, and halogen content. Model evaluations were conducted with the 3D SOCOL-AERv2 chemistry-climate-aerosol model and included a total of 1110 individual model evaluations, totaling 7770 model years. Six representative volcanoes were studied as proxies to investigate the latitudinal dependence of the volcanic eruption on stratospheric ozone. The importance of the time of year that a volcanic eruption occurs and the impact of halogen co-injection into the stratosphere with sulfur dioxide were further investigated by modeling volcanic eruptions in multiple seasons and with differing amounts of chlorine and bromine.

Our results show that stratospheric aerosols and ozone have a strong dependence on volcanic eruption latitude for all scenarios investigated. Higher latitude eruptions tend to produce a large regional-to-hemispheric impact on ozone and a smaller global impact, whereas tropical eruptions tend to exert a more global ozone impact. Changes in total column ozone and aerosol surface area density return to baseline values approximately 2.5-3 years after the eruption regardless of latitude or season for the sulfur dioxide only injection scenario (5 Tg). Increasing the quantity of halogens co-injected in the eruption column increases the degree of ozone depletion and its extent and duration. In all the eruption scenarios investigated, the impact from a volcanic eruption on stratospheric ozone has some dependence on seasonality, with greater changes in ozone following a winter eruption compared to a summer eruption. For the high-halogen co-injection scenarios investigated, there are large ozone losses in both hemispheres, regardless of the eruption latitude or season, with recovery exceeding 4 years. The resulting impact to life on Earth in such a scenario would likely be substantial.

In a separate modeling effort as part of this project using the AER-2D chemistry transport model, we determined the bromine alpha factor (the relative ozone destroying power of a bromine atom relative to chlorine) in future climate states. We introduced a new concept, the eta factor, defined as the ozone destroying power of an atom of chlorine or bromine in a perturbed climate state relative to the ozone destroying power of an atom of chlorine in a benchmark climate state. We quantified eta factors for both chlorine and bromine in the four RCP scenario greenhouse gas emissions pathways, showing that, even though the bromine alpha factor does not appear to differ from its contemporary values in some climate projections, the actual rates of ozone destruction by the bromine and chlorine atoms vary significantly. We then applied the new concept of the eta factor to the definition of Equivalent Effective Stratospheric Chlorine (EESC) to derive a new proxy, Equivalent Effective Stratospheric Benchmark-normalized Chlorine (EESBnC) and demonstrated that this new metric provides parameterized estimates of ozone recovery that agree much more closely with more complex 3D model realizations than estimates of ozone recovery using EESC alone.

Another modeling effort using the AER-2D chemistry transport model determined the iodine alpha factor, providing it as a function of the four RCP scenarios. As with bromine, we quantified for the first time, the iodine eta factor. The new metrics determined in this project allow the atmospheric sciences community to better understand the capability of the inorganic halogen content of the stratosphere to destroy ozone in the future. For example, we showed that, while the stratosphere might cool significantly in the future, depending on the exact climate trajectory realized, bromine will remain significantly more active with regard to ozone destruction than chlorine. In another example, we demonstrated that the iodine alpha factor is climate-sensitive, increasing by as much as a factor of two by the end of the century, but this large increase in some scenarios is primarily due to the suppression of chlorine-mediated ozone destruction.

This project provided training and professional development for two postdoctoral fellows, three research associates, and two undergraduates. Three of the individuals are from underrepresented groups. We have undergraduate co-authors on multiple publications. Our published work is referenced in the WMO Ozone Assessment, the authoritative international document on the state of Earth's ozone layer.
